revision.comment: He became prof. emeritus in 1981, forced by German law. Prof. emeritus will hold till death in Germany.
revision.text:
{{For|the German geologist|Karl von Seebach}} [[File:Karl Seebach.jpg|thumb|Karl Seebach]] '''Karl Seebach''' (June 28, 1912 in [[Munich]] – July 18, 2007 in Munich) was a [[Germany|German]] [[mathematician]].
Seebach earned his doctorate at the [[University of Munich]] under [[Heinrich Tietze]] and [[Arnold Sommerfeld]], in 1938.<ref> [http://genealogy.math.ndsu.nodak.edu/html/id.phtml?id=62146 Seebach] – Mathematics Genealogy Project. 1938 Dissertation title: ''Über die Erweiterung des Definitionsbereiches differenzierbarer Funktionen''. Advisor 1: Heinrich Tietze. Advisor 2: Arnold Sommerfeld.</ref> From 1977 to 1981, he held the Chair for Didactics of Mathematics at the University of Munich.<ref> [http://www.mathematik.uni-muenchen.de/festschrift/node134.html Seebach] - Prof Dr., geb. 28.6.1912, 1977-1981 Inhaber des Lehrstuhls für Didaktik der Mathematik.</ref>
Seebach was the author of many mathematics textbooks for the [[Gymnasium (school)|Gymnasium]].<ref> [http://www.mathematik.uni-muenchen.de/~fmwus/download/ausgabe07.pdf Seebach] – Gymnasium Textbook Author.</ref>
==Books== *Josef Breuer, Paul Knabe, Josef Lauter, Karl Seebach, and Klaus Wigand ''Handbuch der Schulmatematik: Band 2 Algebra'' (Hermann Schroedel) *Johannes Blume, Gerhard Frey, Heinrich Gall, Paul Knabe, Paul Mönnig, Karl Seebach, and Klaus Wigand ''Handbuch der Schulmathematik: Band 5 Einzelfragen der Mathematik'' (Hermann Schroedel) *Ludwig Schecher and Karl Seebach ''Einführung in die Mathematik. Bd. 1'' (Schmidt, 1950) *Karl Seebach and Reinhold Federle ''Vorschläge zum Aufbau der Analytischen Geometrie in vektorieller Behandlung'' (Ehrenwirth, 1965) *Friedrich Barth, Karl Seebach, and Ernst Winkler ''Vorschläge zur Behandlung der geometrischen Abbildungen in der Ebene'' (Ehrenwirth, 1968) *Karl Seebach and Edmund Kösel ''Arbeitsblätter zum Lehrerkolleg. Hauptschule. Schuljahr 9. H. 3. Mathematik, Physik, Chemie'' (TR-Verlagsunion, 1969)
==Notes== <references/>

Susan Adams | relatives = [[Bijou Phillips]] (paternal half-sister)
{{nowrap|[[Chynna Phillips]] (paternal half-sister)}} Jeffery Phillips (brother)
Tamberlane Phillips (brother) }} '''Laura Mackenzie Phillips''' (born November 10, 1959) is an American [[actress]] and [[singing|singer]] best known for her roles in ''[[American Graffiti]]'', as rebellious teenager Julie Mora Cooper Horvath on the sitcom ''[[One Day at a Time]]'', and for the [[Disney Channel]] [[science fiction]] show ''[[So Weird]]''.{{cite news| url=https://movies.nytimes.com/person/534879/Mackenzie-Phillips| title=The New York Times| newspaper=The New York Times}}{{dead link|date=September 2018}} == Early life == Born in [[Alexandria, Virginia]], she is the daughter of [[John Phillips (musician)|John Phillips]], singer in [[The Mamas & the Papas]], and his first wife, Susan Adams. She is the sister of Jeffrey Phillips and a half-sister of Tamerlane Phillips, actress [[Bijou Phillips]], and singer [[Chynna Phillips]]. Phillips attended [[Highland Hall Waldorf School]] in Northridge, California.{{cite book |first=Mackenzie |last=Phillips |title=High on Arrival |publisher=Simon Spotlight Entertainment |place=New York |date=September 23, 2009 |isbn=978-1-4391-5757-2 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HBOSVciLcEsC&dq=high+on+arrival&q=highland+hall#v=snippet&q=highland%20hall&f=false |pages=14-16}} At age 12, Phillips formed a band with three of her classmates and was spotted by a casting agent during one of their performances.{{cite web |title=Mackenzie Phillips Biography (1959-) |publisher=[[The Biography Channel]] |url=http://www.biography.com/search/article.do?id=9542290 |accessdate=November 16, 2008}} She was given an audition for a role in the 1973 hit film ''[[American Graffiti]]'', which she won. == Career == Phillips was 12 years old during the filming of ''[[American Graffiti]]'', and 13 when the movie was released. She was cast as Carol Morrison, a young girl accidentally picked up by [[hot rod]]ding teenager John Milner ([[Paul Le Mat]]). Because of California state law, producer [[Gary Kurtz]] became Phillips' [[legal guardian]] for the duration of the filming.{{cite book| last=Baxter| first=John| title=Mythmaker: The Life and Work of George Lucas| publisher=Harper Collins| year=1999| isbn=978-0-3809-7833-5}} [[File:One Day at a Time female cast 1975.jpg|160px|thumb|left|Mackenzie Phillips in 1975. She is seen here alongside fellow cast members [[Bonnie Franklin]] and [[Valerie Bertinelli]]]] Phillips gained stardom in the 1970s, when she played boy-crazy teenager Julie Cooper (when the character got married, her married name was Horvath) on the long-running television show ''[[One Day at a Time]]'', for which she earned $50,000 (equal to ${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|50000|1975}}}} today) a week. During the show's third season in 1977, Phillips was arrested for [[Disorderly conduct#United States|disorderly conduct]]. Because of her drug and alcohol abuse, Phillips began arriving late and was even incoherent for rehearsals. The producers ordered her to take a six-week break to overcome her addiction but were ultimately forced to fire her in 1980. After two near-fatal [[Drug overdose|overdoses]], Phillips voluntarily entered Fair Oaks Hospital to undergo treatment. After she completed treatment in 1981, the producers of ''One Day at a Time'' invited her back to the show. However, in 1982, Phillips resumed her [[cocaine]] use and the following year, she collapsed on the show's set. When she refused to take a drug test, she was fired again, this time for good. Her character was written out of the series. In 1992, she entered a long-term drug rehabilitation program and underwent intensive treatment for nine months. From the mid 1980s to the early 1990s, Phillips performed with a re-formed version of The Mamas & the Papas, known as [[The New Mamas and The Papas]]. In 1999, Phillips co-starred with [[Cara DeLizia]] in the Disney Channel series ''[[So Weird]]'', playing a fictional rock star named Molly Phillips. She sang original songs written by show producers [[Jon Cooksey]] and Ann Marie Montade. In 2002, she appeared in the Disney Channel original movie ''[[Double Teamed]]''. Phillips guest-starred on episodes of ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'', ''[[Without a Trace]]'', ''[[7th Heaven (TV series)|7th Heaven]]'', and ''[[Cold Case (TV series)|Cold Case]]''. Phillips won an Honorary Best Actress award on March 20, 2011, at the closing night awards gala of the Female Eye Film Festival in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada, for her performance as Sharon in the 2010 independent film ''Peach Plum Pear''. While in Toronto, she was interviewed on ''Canada Am'', ''ET Canada'', and ''[[Marilyn Denis|The Marilyn Denis Show]] ''.{{cite press release |url=http://www.wireservice.ca/index.php?module=News&func=display&sid=4844 |title=9th Female Eye Festival Reveals Mackenzie Phillips & Alanna Masterson As Special Performance Award Recipients |publisher=Female Eye Film Festival |via=Skylar Entertainment |date=March 10, 2011 |accessdate=2018-09-20}} She currently works at the Breathe Life Healing Center in [[West Hollywood, California]], as a drug rehab counselor.{{cite press release| url=http://www.cbs8.com/story/31467518/mackenzie-phillips-joins-breathe-life-healing-centers-as-addiction-counselort| title=Mackenzie Phillips Joins Breathe as Addiction Counselor| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315141137/http://www.cbs8.com/story/31467518/mackenzie-phillips-joins-breathe-life-healing-centers-as-addiction-counselort| date=March 15, 2016| work=[[KFMB-TV]] News| archive-date=March 15, 2016| accessdate=2018-09-20}} In 2017, Phillips appeared in an episode of the rebooted ''[[One Day at a Time (2017 TV series)|One Day at a Time]]'', featured as Pam Valentine. The role was apt, given Phillips' history: she portrayed a counselor. [[File:Mackenzie Phillips.jpg|160px|thumb|right|Phillips in 2008]] In 2018, Phillips appeared as Barbara Denning in multiple episodes of Netflix original ''Orange is the New Black''. ==Personal life== Phillips has been married three times: first to rock group manager Jeffrey Sessler, son of [[Freddie Sessler]] (from 1979 to 1981); then to rock guitarist [[Michael Barakan]] – now known professionally as [[Shane Fontayne]] (1986-2000). She has one child, son Shane Barakan (born 1987), a musician. Her third marriage was in June 2005 to Keith Levenson. ===Substance abuse and arrest=== Phillips has had a lifetime troubled by drug abuse. On August 27, 2008, she was arrested by the [[Los Angeles Airport Police]] on charges of possession of [[cocaine]] and [[heroin]] after she went through airport security screening.{{cite news| title=Mackenzie Phillips arrested at LAX on suspicion of narcotics possession| agency=[[Reuters]]| date=August 28, 2008| url=https://www.seattletimes.com/entertainment/mackenzie-phillips-arrested-at-lax-on-suspicion-of-narcotics-possession/| accessdate=2018-09-20| newspaper=[[The Seattle Times]]}} On October 31, 2008, she pleaded guilty to one felony count of cocaine possession, and was sentenced to a drug rehabilitation program.{{cite news| title=Mackenzie Phillips Pleads Guilty to Cocaine Possession| magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]]| date=October 31, 2008| url=https://people.com/crime/mackenzie-phillips-pleads-guilty-to-cocaine-possession/| accessdate=2018-09-20| first=Ken| last=Lee}} Phillips' drug case was dismissed after she successfully completed a drug diversion program.{{cite news| url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/people/2010-04-30-mackenzie-phillips-charge_N.htm| title=Drug case dismissed against Mackenzie Phillips| newspaper=[[USA Today]]| date=April 20, 2010| agency=[[Associated Press]]}} She appeared on the third season of ''[[Celebrity Rehab#Cast 3|Celebrity Rehab]]'', which aired in January and February 2010. She later discussed her recovery on the March 17, 2010, episode of ''[[The View (U.S. TV series)|The View]]''.[http://www.tvguide.com/tvshows/the-view/episode-14313875/192276/ Episode guide: ''The View'', first aired: March 17, 2010], ''[[TV Guide]]'' ===Relationship with father=== In September 2009, Phillips's memoir ''High on Arrival'' was released, after which she appeared on ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'' for an hour-long interview. She told Winfrey that she first tried cocaine when she was 11 years old, and that her father had taken drugs with her, and had also injected her with [[cocaine]]. During the interview, Phillips read excerpts from her book. She said that at the age of 19, on the night before her first wedding, "I woke up that night from a blackout to find myself having sex with my own father", and that when she confronted her father months later,''High On Arrival'' p. 110 asking why he had raped her, her father simply replied, "Raped you? Don't you mean we made love?"[http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/mackenzie-phillips-sexual-affair-dad/story?id=8647172 ABC News9/23/09] Phillips told [[Oprah Winfrey]] of having a [[consent|consensual]] sexual relationship with her father,{{cite news| url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/09/24/earlyshow/leisure/celebspot/main5335218.shtml| title=New Bombshell from Mackenzie Phillips| date=2009-09-24| website=[[CBS News]]| accessdate=2009-09-25}} describing her participation as "sort of [[Stockholm Syndrome]], where you begin to love your captor."{{cite news |url=http://entertainment.timesonline.co.uk/tol/arts_and_entertainment/music/article6847215.ece |title=Mackenzie Phillips, daughter of Mamas and Papas star, reveals their incestuous affair |last=Schmidt |first=Veronica |date=2009-09-24|newspaper=[[The Times]] |accessdate=2009-09-25 |location=London}} [[Genevieve Waite|Geneviève Waïte]], who was John's wife at the time MacKenzie claimed the incest first began, denies the allegations, saying they were inconsistent with his character. [[Michelle Phillips]], John's second wife, also stated that she had "every reason to believe [Mackenzie's account is] untrue."{{cite news |last=Eng |first=Joyce |title=Mackenzie Phillips' Family Split Over Star's Incest Claims |magazine=[[TV Guide]] |url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/mackenzie-phillips-family-1010113/ |accessdate=2009-09-24}} However, [[Chynna Phillips]], Mackenzie's half-sister and Michelle Phillips' daughter, stated that she believed Mackenzie's claims and that Mackenzie first told her about the relationship during a phone conversation in 1997, approximately 11 years after the supposed relationship had ended.{{cite news |last=Everett |first=Cristina |title=Chynna Phillips recalls learning about sister Mackenzie Phillips' affair with father, John Phillips |newspaper=[[New York Daily News]] |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/gossip/2009/09/23/2009-09-23_chynna_phillips_recalls_learning_about_sister_mackenzie_phillips_affair_with_fat.html |accessdate=2009-09-24 |date=2009-09-23}} == Filmography == {| class="wikitable sortable" |+Film |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- |1973 || ''[[American Graffiti]]'' || Carol Morrison || |- |1975 || ''[[Rafferty and the Gold Dust Twins]]'' || Rita "Frisbee" Sykes || |- |1979 || ''[[More American Graffiti]]'' || Carol "Rainbow" Morrison || |- |1982 || ''[[Love Child (1982 film)|Love Child]]'' || J.J. || |- |1998 || ''[[True Friends (1998 film)|True Friends]]'' || Connie || |- |1999 || ''[[When (film)|When]]'' || Catherine Brown || |- |2005 || ''{{sortname|The|Jacket}}'' ||Nurse Harding || |- |2011 || ''[[Hercules Saves Christmas]]'' || Helen Dunn || Alternate title: ''Santa's Dog'' |- |2011 || ''[[Peach Plum Pear]]'' || Sharon || |- |2014 || ''[[Suburban Gothic (film)|Suburban Gothic]]'' || Mrs. Richards || |- |2014 || ''[[Blackout (2014 film)|Blackout]]'' || Sarah || Short film |- |2014 || ''[[North Blvd]]'' || Linda || |- |2015 || ''[[Girl on the Edge]]'' || Deborah Green || |- |2016 || ''[[Sacred Journeys]]'' || Tiff || Short film |- |2018 || ''North Blvd'' || Linda || |- |} {| class="wikitable sortable" |+Television |- ! Year ! Title ! revision.text:
{{Multiple issues|{{BLP primary sources|date=March 2018}}{{Third-party|date=March 2018}}{{Orphan|date=March 2018}}}}
'''McKinley L. Blackburn''' is a [[United States|U.S.-American]] [[economist]] and currently the James A. Morris Professor of Economics at the [[University of South Carolina]].<ref>[https://sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/moore/directory/blackburn_mckinley.php Profile of McKinley Blackburn on the website of the University of South Carolina. Retrieved March 22nd, 2018.]</ref> His research interests include [[labour economics]], [[econometrics]], and [[economic demography]].<ref>[https://sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/moore/documents/economics/blackburn_cv_january_2018.pdf Curriculum vitae of McKinley Blackburn from the website of the University of South Carolina. Retrieved March 22nd, 2018.]</ref>
== Biography==
McKinley Blackburn earned a [[Bachelor of Science|B.S.]] in economics from the [[University of South Carolina]] in 1982, followed by a [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] and a [[Ph.D.]] in economics from [[Harvard University]] in 1985 and 1987. Since his graduation, Blackburn has always held a position at the University of South Carolina, first as assistant professor pf economics (1987–93), then as associate professor (1993–98) and finally as full professor (1998-2010). In 2010, he was made the James A. Morris Professor of Economics at the [[Darla Moore School of Business]]. In 1989/90, Blackburn spent a year as visiting scholar at the [[Russell Sage Foundation]]. In terms of professional service, Blackburn has performed editorial duties for the ''[[Economics of Education Review]]'' since 2008. His research has been recognized with the Aldi J.M. Hagenaars Memorial Award (1994) and the Research Development Award of the Darla Moore School of Business.<ref>[https://sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/moore/documents/economics/blackburn_cv_january_2018.pdf Curriculum vitae of McKinley Blackburn from the website of the University of South Carolina. Retrieved March 22nd, 2018.]</ref>
== Research==
McKinley Blackburn's current research focuses on the effects of [[minimum wage]]s on [[employment]], the econometric estimation of the effect of individual characteristics on [[wage]]s, and the behaviour of banks in mortgage markets.<ref>[https://sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/moore/directory/blackburn_mckinley.php Profile of McKinley Blackburn on the website of the University of South Carolina.]</ref> According to [[IDEAS/RePEc]], Blackburn belongs to the top 6% of economists registered in the database in terms of research output.<ref>[https://ideas.repec.org/top/top.person.all.html Ranking of economists registered on IDEAS/RePEc. Retrieved March 22nd, 2018.]</ref> Key findings of his research include the following: * The increases in the [[Mincerian equations|returns to schooling]] observed in the [[United States|U.S.]] during the 1980s cannot be attributed to a change in the relationship between ability and schooling wherein higher returns to schooling would have e.g. masked an increase in the average ability of graduates (with [[David Neumark]]).<ref>[https://ideas.repec.org/a/ucp/jlabec/v11y1993i3p521-44.html Blackburn, M., Neumark, D. (1993). Omitted-Ability Bias and the Increase in the Return to Schooling. ''Journal of Labor Economics'', 11(3), pp. 521-544.]</ref> * Together with [[David E. Bloom]] and [[Richard B. Freeman]], Blackburn documents the strong deterioration of the economic position of less-skilled American males in the 1970s and 1980s, which the authors attribute to a combination of [[deindustrialization]], [[deunionization]], and changes in the growth rates of different education groups, but find no role for decreases in the minimum wage, technological change, increased female labour market participation, and changes in the quality of less-educated workers.<ref>[https://ideas.repec.org/p/nbr/nberwo/3186.html Blackburn, M.L., Bloom, D.E., Freeman, R.B. (1989). The Declining Economic Position of Less-Skilled American Males. ''NBER Working Paper Series'', 3186.]</ref> * Contrary the downward bias in the [[Ordinary least squares|OLS]] estimates of the returns to schooling in the U.S. found in earlier research, Blackburn and Neumark find that OLS estimates which fail to control for ability overestimate returns to schooling by 40%.<ref>[https://ideas.repec.org/a/tpr/restat/v77y1995i2p217-30.html Blackburn, M.L., Neumark, D. (1995). Are OLS Estimates of the Return to Schooling Biased Downward? Another Look. ''Review of Economics and Statistics'', 77(2), pp. 217-230.]</ref> *Differences in unobserved ability appear to explain only a small share of wage differentials between industries and occupations in the U.S. (with Neumark).<ref>[https://ideas.repec.org/a/oup/qjecon/v107y1992i4p1421-1436..html Blackburn, M., Neumark, D. (1992). Unobserved Ability, Efficiency Wages, and Interindustry Differentials. ''Quarterly Journal of Economics'', 107(4), pp. 1421-1436.]</ref> * Increases in [[minimum wage]]s in the U.S. between 1983 and 1996 appear to have reduced poverty among teenagers and older dropouts from [[junior high school]]s (with [[John T. Addison]]).<ref>[https://ideas.repec.org/a/sae/ilrrev/v52y1999i3p393-409.html Addison, J.T., Blackburn, M. L. (1999). Minimum Wages and Poverty. ''ILR Review'', 52(3), pp. 393-409.]</ref> * [[Unemployment insurance]] may have increased the wages of workers in the U.S. after the end of their unemployment spells, though less than indicated by earlier research.<ref>[https://ideas.repec.org/a/eee/labeco/v7y2000i1p21-53.html Addison, J.T., Blackburn, M.L. (2000). The effects of unemployment insurance on postunemployment earnings. ''Labour economics'', 7(1), pp. 21-53.]</ref>
== References==
{{reflist}}
== External links==
* [https://sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/moore/directory/blackburn_mckinley.php Webpage of McKinley Blackburn on the website of the University of South Carolina]

The incumbent minister is Peter Adwok Nyaba, while Gabriel Kuc Abyei serves as deputy minister.Government of South Sudan official Website: Ministry of Higher Education, Science and Technology {{cite web |url=http://www.goss-online.org/magnoliaPublic/en/ministries/High-Education--Research--Science-and-Technology.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://swap.stanford.edu/20110310174038/http://www.goss-online.org/magnoliaPublic/en/ministries/High-Education--Research--Science-and-Technology.html |archivedate=2011-03-10 |df= }} ==List of Ministers of Higher Education, Science and Technology== {| class="wikitable" |- !Minister of Higher Education, Science and Technology !In Office !Party !President !Note(s) |- | [[Peter Adwok Nyaba]] | Since July 2011 | [[Sudan People's Liberation Movement]] | [[Salva Kiir Mayardit]] | 2014 |- | [[Dr. John Gai Yoh]] | Since August 2014 | [[SPLM]] | [[Salva Kiir Mayardit]] | to 2016 |- |} ==See also== * [[Ministry of Education, Science and Technology (South Sudan)]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Government ministries of South Sudan}} [[Category:Government ministries of South Sudan|Higher Education, Science and Technology]] [[Category:Education ministries|South Sudan, Higher Education, Science and Technology]] [[Category:Ministries established in 2011|South Sudan, Higher Education, Science and Technology]] {{SouthSudan-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=January 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox person |honorific_prefix = Doctor |name = Naoisé O'Reilly |image = Naoisé O'Reilly.jpg |caption = Naoisé O'Reilly in London, United Kingdom during London 2012 Olympic Games |nationality = Irish |occupation = Personality theory researcher, physical oceanographer, observational scientist, educationalist |known_for = Personality theory, learning difficulties research, four learning styles |website = {{URL|drnaoiseoreilly.org}} }}
'''Naoisé O'Reilly''' is a [[psychology]] expert who develops methods in the areas of expression and psychological profiling.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Yagi|first1=Randy|title=San Francisco Psychology Expert Advises Students To Pick What They're Good At|url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2014/11/03/san-francisco-psychology-expert-advises-students-to-pick-what-theyre-good-at/|accessdate=28 February 2015|publisher=CBS|date=3 November 2014}}</ref> She earned a PhD Doctorate in physical oceanography from the National Oceanography Centre<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Dr. Naoisé|title=The Purple View|date=1 April 2012|publisher=The Homework Club|isbn=095654651X|page=40|url=http://www.bookdepository.com/Purple-View-Dr-Naoise-OReilly/9780956546517|accessdate=3 March 2015}}</ref> at the [[University of Southampton]], United Kingdom in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|title=Academic Distinctions Past Pupils|url=http://www.kingshospitalppu.ie/thekingshospital/Main/Academic_AchievementsPP.htm|website=The King's Hospital|publisher=The King's Hospital|accessdate=28 February 2015}}</ref> The [[British Library]] catalogued her PhD [[dissertation]] entitled ''Combining Altimetry and Hydrography with Inverse Methods''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Explore The British Library|url=http://explore.bl.uk/primo_library/libweb/action/display.do?tabs=moreTab&ct=display&fn=search&doc=BLL01014540593&indx=1&recIds=BLL01014540593&recIdxs=0&elementId=0&renderMode=poppedOut&displayMode=full&frbrVersion=&dscnt=2&fromLogin=true&tab=local_tab&dstmp=1425140700107&vl(freeText0)=naoise%20o%27reilly&vid=BLVU1&mode=Basic|website=The British Library|publisher=The British Library|accessdate=28 February 2015}}</ref> Outlined as one of the conclusions, O'Reilly developed an [[oceanography]] [[satellite]] altimetry and argo float [[big data]] scientific research [[system]] to analyse the state of the north Atlantic Ocean in three dimensional surface elevations.<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Dr. Naoisé|title=Combining Altimetry and Hydrography with Inverse Methods: As applied to Satellite Altimetry|date=28 August 2009|publisher=VDM Verlag|isbn=3639192257|page=163|url=https://www.amazon.com/Combining-Altimetry-Hydrography-Inverse-Methods/dp/3639192257/ref=asap_bc?ie=UTF8|accessdate=2 March 2015}}</ref> She graduated from the [[National University of Ireland, Galway]] in 2000 with a first class honours degree in marine science.<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Naoisé|title=The Homework Club Workbook: Primary and Secondary Tuition|date=10 May 2010|publisher=The Homework Club|isbn=0956546501|page=50|url=https://www.amazon.com/Homework-Club-Workbook-Primary-Secondary/dp/0956546501/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1425233216&sr=8-2&keywords=naoise+o%27reilly|accessdate=1 March 2015}}</ref> She studied quantitative Earth observations at the [[University of Oxford]] and geophysical and environmental fluid dynamics at the [[University of Cambridge]] in 2002.<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Dr. Naoisé|title=The Purple View|date=1 April 2012|publisher=The Homework Club|isbn=095654651X|page=47|url=http://www.bookdepository.com/Purple-View-Dr-Naoise-OReilly/9780956546517|accessdate=3 March 2015}}</ref>
== Dyslexia == O'Reilly has severe [[dyslexia]] and as a teenager an [[educational psychologist]] said she was not suited to attend college. She says [[literacy]] is not a gauge of [[intelligence]]<ref>{{cite news|last1=Leonard|first1=Sue|title=Purple Success – Helping others realise their dreams|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/lifestyle/features/purple-success--helping-others-realise-their-dreams-230408.html|accessdate=28 February 2015|work=Irish Examiner|date=6 May 2013}}</ref> and that "personality is an inconvenience in school."<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Naoisé|title=The Purple View|date=1 April 2012|publisher=The Homework Club|isbn=095654651X|page=16|url=http://www.bookdepository.com/Purple-View-Dr-Naoise-OReilly/9780956546517|accessdate=3 March 2015}}</ref> In an education and teaching book about getting high school grades she spoke of introducing reward systems in the home for dyslexic children saying "the goal should be achievable and have the right level of challenge."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mukherjee|first1=Geetanjali|title=Anyone Can Get An A+|date=2 September 2015|publisher=Amazon Digital Services|page=53|url=https://www.amazon.com/Anyone-Can-Get-Procrastination-Improve-ebook/dp/B0144W7X4A/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1441719188&sr=8-1&keywords=anyone+can+get+an+a+&pebp=1441719191300&perid=1XK2DQ7Y1TJ14QCCPDS6|accessdate=11 September 2015}}</ref> Interviewed by a journalist in 1999 during her time in university in Ireland O'Reilly said "school is the worst place for a dyslexic."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Donnellan|first1=Eithne|title=Galway Parents Lobby For Special Unit For Children With Reading Difficulties|work=The Tuam herald|date=1 May 1999}}</ref> Her methods examine personality [[theory]]<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Dr. Naoisé|title=The Purple View|date=1 April 2012|publisher=The Homework Club|isbn=095654651X|page=16|url=http://www.bookdepository.com/Purple-View-Dr-Naoise-OReilly/9780956546517|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref> and four [[learning styles]] of auditory, visual, practical and kinesthetic<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Dr. Naoisé|title=The Purple View|date=1 April 2012|publisher=The Homework Club|isbn=095654651X|page=23|url=http://www.bookdepository.com/Purple-View-Dr-Naoise-OReilly/9780956546517|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref> with children and adults in Ireland and around the World.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McGarry|first1=Fiona|title=The Teamwork Approach to Homework: 7 Ways it Can Work for You|url=http://www.herfamily.ie/parenthood/the-teamwork-approach-to-homework-7-ways-it-can-work-for-you/218895|accessdate=1 June 2015|publisher=Her Family|date=1 June 2015}}</ref> She was Anti-Discrimination Officer for the Students' Union and Student Activist for people with disabilities at the National University of Ireland, Galway in addition to National Disability Rights Officer for the Union of Students of Ireland.<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Naoisé|title=The Homework Club Workbook: Primary and Secondary Tuition|date=10 May 2010|publisher=The Homework Club|isbn=0956546501|page=50|url=https://www.amazon.com/Homework-Club-Workbook-Primary-Secondary/dp/0956546501/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1425233216&sr=8-2&keywords=naoise+o%27reilly|accessdate=1 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Healy|first1=Yvonne|title=College Equations|work=The Irish Times|date=8 December 1998}}</ref>
The observational scientist<ref>{{cite news|last1=Prendeville|first1=Tom|title=Oprah Show star is turning firms around|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/irish/oprah-show-star-is-turning-firms-around-29135073.html|accessdate=28 February 2015|work=Sunday Independent|date=17 March 2013}}</ref> and physical oceanographer<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Dr. Naoisé|title=The Purple View|date=1 April 2012|publisher=The Homework Club|isbn=095654651X|page=7|url=http://www.bookdepository.com/Purple-View-Dr-Naoise-OReilly/9780956546517|accessdate=3 March 2015}}</ref> taught at the [[European Space Agency]] Earth Observation Summer School in [[Frascati]], Italy in 2004<ref>{{cite web|title=Earth Observation Summer School|url=https://earth.esa.int/web/eo-summer-school/programme/eo-school-2|publisher=European Space Agency|accessdate=28 February 2015}}</ref> on a course run for postdoctoral researchers interpreting and using [[satellite]] images in [[Earth]] science research. She assisted the Kenya Marine and Fisheries Research Institute in developing a UNESCO<ref>{{cite web|title=African Capacity Building in Satellite Altimetry with the UNESCO-Bilko Programme|url=http://earth.esa.int/cgi-bin/confalt15y2e6a.html?abstract=405|publisher=European Space Agency|accessdate=11 June 2016}}</ref> postgraduate level workshop called the Application of Satellite Altimetry to Oceanography. This was a training course for the western Indian Ocean region run in Africa for postdoctoral students in 2004. She addressed the [[European Geosciences Union]] general assembly in [[Nice]], France in 2004 and her works were presented at an Argo Science workshop in [[Venice]], Italy in 2006.<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Dr. Naoisé|title=The Purple View|date=1 April 2012|publisher=The Homework Club|isbn=095654651X|page=47|url=http://www.bookdepository.com/Purple-View-Dr-Naoise-OReilly/9780956546517|accessdate=3 March 2015}}</ref>
== Education methods == A series of educational methods for students with learning difficulties called the Purple Learning Project were developed by O'Reilly in an education centre she founded in 2009 called the Homework Club located in Blanchardstown, Dublin, Ireland.<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Dr. Naoisé|title=The Purple View|date=1 April 2012|publisher=The Homework Club|isbn=095654651X|page=7|url=http://www.bookdepository.com/Purple-View-Dr-Naoise-OReilly/9780956546517|accessdate=3 March 2015}}</ref> Classes are not created based on age or academic level but student [[personality type]] and ability.<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Dr. Naoisé|title=The Purple View|date=1 April 2012|publisher=The Homework Club|isbn=095654651X|page=10|url=http://www.bookdepository.com/Purple-View-Dr-Naoise-OReilly/9780956546517|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref> Classroom sizes are capped with a maximum of ten students per class taught by honours university graduates trained in O'Reilly's teaching methods.<ref>{{cite news|title=The Homework Club|publisher=Irish Tatler|date=July 2010}}</ref> The government of [[Finland]] engaged with research from the Irish educationalist.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Young|first1=David|title=An idle exercise|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/viewpoints/analysis/an-idle-exercise-179147.html|accessdate=5 March 2015|work=Irish Examiner|issue=58931|date=6 January 2012}}</ref> Interviewed for a college in the United States about dealing with difficult children the personality theory researcher and educationalist placed importance on investigating the environment and surroundings when problems frequently emerge to help discover what triggers can spark behaviour.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Flavin|first1=Brianna|title=Education Experts Share 10 Tips for Dealing with a Difficult Child|url=http://rasmussen.edu/degrees/education/blog/dealing-with-a-difficult-child/|accessdate=19 May 2015|publisher=Rasmussen College|date=4 May 2015}}</ref> O'Reilly has said "I read backwards and see the world in reverse. In fact my own PhD research was an inverse method."<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Dr. Naoisé|title=The Purple View|date=1 April 2012|publisher=The Homework Club|isbn=095654651X|page=7|url=http://www.bookdepository.com/Purple-View-Dr-Naoise-OReilly/9780956546517|accessdate=14 March 2015}}</ref> Other educational methods developed by O'Reilly include the Experience Effect and the Gap Effect.<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Dr. Naoisé|title=The Homework Club Workbook: Primary and Secondary Tuition|date=10 May 2010|publisher=The Homework Club|isbn=0956546501|page=5|url=https://www.amazon.com/Homework-Club-Workbook-Primary-Secondary/dp/0956546501/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1425404300&sr=8-1&keywords=naoise+o%27reilly|accessdate=3 March 2015}}</ref>
== Learning difficulties == [[Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder]] is an area she has been described as an expert in<ref>{{cite web|last1=Warner|first1=Jeremy|title=ADHD Treatments and Remedies: Top ADHD Experts Share Their Secrets to Success|url=https://www.amazon.com/ADHD-Treatments-Remedies-Experts-Secrets-ebook/dp/B00C90GGOS/ref=sr_1_8?ie=UTF8&qid=1425213950&sr=8-8&keywords=jeremy+warner|publisher=Amazon.com|accessdate=1 March 2015}}</ref> and supporting people with [[Asperger syndrome]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Regional Services|url=http://www.aspireireland.ie/index.php?Itemid=123|website=Aspire The Asperger Syndrome Association of Ireland|publisher=Aspire The Asperger Syndrome Association of Ireland|accessdate=28 February 2015}}</ref> dyslexia, [[developmental co-ordination disorder]], [[dyscalculia]], dysgraphia, hearing impairments, expression disorders and depression.<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Dr. Naoisé|title=The Purple View|date=1 April 2012|publisher=The Homework Club|isbn=095654651X|page=44|url=http://www.bookdepository.com/Purple-View-Dr-Naoise-OReilly/9780956546517|accessdate=3 March 2015}}</ref>
== Personality theory == The educational innovator<ref>{{cite news|last1=McGarry|first1=Fiona|title=The Teamwork Approach to Homework: 7 Ways it Can Work for You|url=http://www.herfamily.ie/parenthood/the-teamwork-approach-to-homework-7-ways-it-can-work-for-you/218895|accessdate=1 June 2015|publisher=Her Family|date=1 June 2015}}</ref> made a breakthrough in psychology research with [[Marie O'Riordan]] in 2013<ref>{{cite news|title=The secret of success|url=http://www.herald.ie/news/the-secret-of-success-29200189.html|accessdate=28 February 2015|work=Herald|date=16 April 2013}}</ref> by developing the Periodic Table of the Development of Results. The [[formula]] is also called Purple Success.<ref>{{cite news|title=Secrets To Success Formula Revealed By Purple Learning Project Scientist's Invention of Periodic Table of the Development of Results with The Forever Method|url=http://markets.financialcontent.com/mi.miamiherald/news/read/23905058/Secrets_To_Success_Formula_Revealed_By_Purple_Learning_Project_Scientist's_Invention_Of_Periodic_Table_Of_The_Development_of_Results_with_The_Forever_Method|accessdate=1 March 2015|work=The Miami Herald|date=11 April 2013}}</ref> O'Reilly has an [[INFJ]] personality type.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Berg|first1=Marie Grace|title=Today's Leading Women Podcast|url=http://todaysleadingwomen.com/naoise-oreilly/|website=Today's Leading Women|publisher=Today's Leading Women|accessdate=17 November 2015}}</ref>
== Awards == O'Reilly's the Homework Club was awarded O2 Ability Company status by international [[disability]] rights group Kanchi in 2010 along with [[Citi]], EMC, [[Microsoft]] Ireland and [[Trinity College Dublin]].<ref>{{cite news|title=The Winners|work=The Irish Times|date=14 May 2010}}</ref> Former [[President of Ireland]] and former United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights [[Mary Robinson]] was on stage<ref>{{cite news|title=The Winners|work=The Irish Times|date=14 May 2010}}</ref> and the awards were broadcast live on [[Newstalk]] national radio.<ref>{{cite web|title=O2 Ability Awards Ability Companies Revealed|url=http://theabilityawards.com/uncategorized/ability-companies-revealed|website=The Ability Awards|publisher=The Ability Awards|accessdate=28 February 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150228173128/http://theabilityawards.com/uncategorized/ability-companies-revealed|archivedate=28 February 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Dublin 15 Chamber presented her with two awards for Best New Business 2009<ref>{{cite book|last1=O'Reilly|first1=Dr. Naoisé|title=The Homework Club Workbook: Primary and Secondary Tuition|date=10 May 2010|publisher=The Homework Club|isbn=0956546501|page=49|url=https://www.amazon.com/Homework-Club-Workbook-Primary-Secondary/dp/0956546501/ref=sr_1_2?ie=UTF8&qid=1425324991&sr=8-2&keywords=naoise+o%27reilly|accessdate=2 March 2015}}</ref> and Small Business of the Year 2010 for the Homework Club.<ref>{{cite news|work=Blanch Gazette|date=25 August 2011}}</ref> The education centre was nominated for an AIB Innovation in Business Excellence award at the Fingal Business Excellence Awards 2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Roll of Honour: Fingal Business Excellence Awards 2011.|url=http://www.independent.ie/regionals/fingalindependent/news/roll-of-honour-fingal-business-excellence-awards-2011-27813527.html|accessdate=1 March 2015|work=The Irish Independent|date=8 November 2011}}</ref>
== Media == She called for [[homework]] to be banned in schools during an Irish national radio interview in studio with [[Derek Mooney]] on the Mooney show on [[RTÉ]] Radio One on 11 November 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mooney Archive 2011: November|url=http://www.rte.ie/radio/mooneygoeswild/archive/index_nov2011.html|publisher=Raidió Teilifís Éireann|accessdate=28 February 2015}}</ref> Interviewed by Shane Coleman in studio on Irish national radio show The Right Hook broadcast on Newstalk on 29 October 2015 about plans to ban homework in Oslo, Norway she said Irish people should refuse to do homework and referenced homework boycotts in France.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Coleman|first1=Shane|title=The Right Hook|url=http://www.newstalk.com/listen_back/9/22600/29th_October_2015_-_The_Right_Hook_Part_1/|accessdate=30 October 2015|publisher=Newstalk|date=29 October 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Oreilly, Naoise}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Philosophers of education]] [[Category:Irish psychologists]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Southampton]] [[Category:Alumni of the National University of Ireland]] [[Category:People diagnosed with dyslexia]]

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[Science center]] (link changed to [[Science museum#Science_center]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
'''The Nature Exchange''' is a specialized learning environment that encourages people to explore nature and actively observe, collect, study and share the world around them. It is a turn-key exhibit, now used in nature-based institutions around [[North America]]. Developed by [[Science North]] and [[AldrichPears Associates]], the Nature Exchange is an interactive forum where visitors trade ethically collected natural objects and information about them to learn and engage with the natural world. Visitors earn points for each trade, based on criteria such as quality, rarity and their knowledge of the item.<ref>[http://sciencenorth.ca/enterprises/work/exhibits/natureexchange/index.html Nature Exchange]</ref> [[Science museum#Science_center|Science center]]s, nature centers and [[zoo]]s use Nature Exchanges to raise awareness of key issues in the natural world, and, through personal interaction, changes attitudes and behavior.<ref>S. Errington, S. Stocklmayer, B. Honeyman, eds. "The Learning Experience in the Nature Exchange", ''Using Museums to Popularize Science and Technology'', 2001</ref>
==Locations== *[[Canadian Bushplane Heritage Centre]], [[Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario]]<ref>[http://www.bushplane.com/index.php?id=natureexchange]</ref> *[[Chattahoochee Nature Center]], [[Roswell, Georgia]] <ref>[http://www.chattnaturecenter.org/interpretive-center/welcome-to-the-nature-exchange/become-a-nature-exchange-expert/ Chattahoochee Nature Center Nature Exchange]</ref> *[[BC Wildlife Park]], [[Kamloops, British Columbia]] <ref>[http://www.bczoo.org/learn-with-usnew.htm BC Wildlife Park Nature Exchange]</ref> *[[Las Vegas Springs Preserve]], [[Nevada]] <ref>[http://www.springspreserve.org/education/exchange.html Las Vegas Springs Preserve Nature Exchange]</ref> *Zoomazium, [[Woodland Park Zoo]] – [[Seattle, Washington]] <ref>[http://www.zoo.org/nature-exchange Zoomazium Nature Exchange]</ref> *[[Tulsa Zoo]], [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]] <ref>[http://www.tulsazoo.org/EducationConservation/NatureExchange/ Tulsa Zoo Nature Exchange]</ref> *[[Kidspace Children's Museum]], [[Pasadena, California]] <ref>[http://www.kidspacemuseum.org/site/PageServer?pagename=pe_prog_ne Kidspace Nature Exchange]</ref> *Exploration Place – [[Prince George, British Columbia]] <ref>[http://theexplorationplace.com/galleries/nature-exchange/ Exploration Place Nature Exchange]</ref> *Lacerte Family Children's Zoo, [[Dallas Zoo]], [[Dallas, Texas]]<ref>[http://www.dallaszoo.com/exhibits-experiences/lacerte-family-childrens-zoo/nature-exchange/ Dallas Zoo Hillcrest Foundation Nature Exchange]</ref> *[[Science North]], [[Sudbury, Ontario]] <ref>[http://www.zoo.org/nature-exchange Science North Nature Exchange]</ref>
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == *[http://sciencenorth.ca/imax3d/index.html Science North] *[http://www.aldrichpears.com AldrichPears Associates] *[http://www.natureexchange.com/ The Nature Exchange]

'''No Isolation'''<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.noisolation.com/en/|title=No Isolation|website=No Isolation}}</ref> is a Norwegian [[startup company]] from [[Oslo]] established October 2015 by [[Karen Dolva]], Marius Aabel and Matias Doyle. The company's mission is “to reduce involuntary loneliness and social isolation by developing communication tools that help those affected.”<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.noisolation.com/about-us/|title=About Us|website=No Isolation|language=en|access-date=2018-08-28}}</ref> Their first product, AV1, a robot for children with [[Chronic condition|long-term illness]], was launched in the [[autumn]] of 2016. Their second product, KOMP, a communication device for seniors, was launched November 2017. No Isolation has won awards for Best Newcomer and Best Social Tech Startup under Nordic Startup Awards in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nordicstartupawards.com/season-2016|title=Nordic Startup Awards - Season 2016|website=Nordic Startup Awards}}</ref> In 2017, they also received the awards Startup of the Year and Best Social Impact Startup.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nordicstartupawards.com/national-winners-2017|title=Nordic Startup Awards {{!}} National Winners 2017|website=Nordic Startup Awards|language=en|access-date=2018-01-18}}</ref> In 2018, they again got the Social Impact award.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://twitter.com/NSAwards/status/1042113759840493568|title=NordicStartupAwards on Twitter|work=Twitter|access-date=2018-10-15|language=en}}</ref> No Isolation has their [[headquarters]] in [[Oslo]], in addition to having offices in [[London]] and [[Amsterdam]]. The company currently employs 44 people. {{Infobox company | name = No Isolation AS | logo = No Isolation.png | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | founded = {{Start date and age|2015|10|01}} | hq_location_city = [[Oslo]], [[Norway]] | num_locations = 3 | area_served = [[Europe]] | products = [[AV1 (robot)|AV1]] and [[KOMP (communication device)|KOMP]] | num_employees = 44 | subsid = No Isolation BV | website = {{URL|https://www.noisolation.com}} }} [[File:AV1.jpg|alt=AV1|thumb|AV1]]
== AV1 == [[AV1 (robot)|AV1]] is the company’s first product. AV1, derived from [[Audio/Video]] and [[Avatar (computing)|Avatar]], is a [[robot]] that helps combat involuntary loneliness and social isolation for children and young adults with long-term illness.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/aug/13/robot-to-help-sick-children-norwegian-start-up|title=The robot that staves off loneliness for chronically ill children|first=Andrew|last=Anthony|date=13 August 2017|publisher=|via=The Guardian}}</ref> It consists of a [[camera]], [[Digital speaker|speaker]] and [[microphone]], that helps the child keep up with [[education]] in the classroom, as well as stay in contact with family and friends, without being physically present.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.econsultancy.com/blog/69338-five-companies-using-robots-and-ai-to-make-a-difference|title=Five companies using robots and AI to make a difference|publisher=}}</ref> The robot has two [[motor]]s, a [[battery (electricity)|battery]] and built-in [[4G]] and [[Wi-Fi|WiFi]], so that it can be used anywhere. The robot is controlled by a [[phone]] or a [[Tablet computer|tablet]] using a [[mobile app]] for [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]].
== KOMP == [[KOMP (communication device)|KOMP]] is the company's second product. It is a [[computer]], often referred to as a ''screen'', with one button, targeted towards [[Senior Citizens|senior citizens]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.noisolation.com/komp|title=KOMP – the communication device for seniors|last=|first=|date=|website=No Isolation|language=en-us|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-01-16}}</ref> [[File:KOMP for seniors.png|alt=KOMP|thumb|KOMP]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links ==
* [https://www.noisolation.com/ Official website] *[https://www.noisolation.com/av1/ AV1] *[https://www.noisolation.com/komp/ KOMP]

[[File:School bullying laws in the United States.svg|thumb|450px| {{legend|#800080|State law that prohibits discrimination against students based on sexual orientation and gender identity}} {{legend|#0066ff|State law that prohibits discrimination against students based on sexual orientation only}} {{legend|#14a800|State law that prohibits bullying of students based on sexual orientation and gender identity}} {{legend|#ba75ff|State school regulation or ethical code for teachers that address discrimination and/or bullying of students based on sexual orientation and gender identity}} {{legend|#00ffff|State school regulation or ethical code for teachers that address discrimination and/or bullying of students based on sexual orientation only}} <nowiki>----</nowiki> {{legend|#d40000|State law that forbids instruction on LGBT issues within public schools}} {{legend|Maroon|State law that forbids local school districts from having anti-bullying policies that enumerate protected classes of students}} <nowiki>----</nowiki> {{legend|#7f7f7f|State law that prohibits bullying in school but lists no categories of protection}} {{legend|#cccccc|No law that specifically prohibits bullying in schools}}]]
'''No promo homo laws''' are laws approved by various [[U.S. states]] that prohibit or limit the mention or discussion of [[homosexuality]] and [[transgender]] identity in [[State school|public schools]]. In theory, these laws mainly apply to [[sex ed]] courses, but they can also be applied to other parts of the school curriculum as well as to extracurricular activities and organizations such as [[gay-straight alliance]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://glsen.org/learn/policy/issues/nopromohomo|title=“No Promo Homo” Laws|website=GLSEN|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref>
These anti-LGBT curriculum laws can be found in [[Alabama]], [[Arizona]], [[Louisiana]], [[Mississippi]], [[Oklahoma]], [[South Carolina]] and [[Texas]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lambdalegal.org/dont-erase-us/faq|title=#DontEraseUs: FAQ About Anti-LGBT Curriculum Laws|publisher=|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref>
They are similar to [[Section 28]] of the [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Local Government Act 1988]], introduced on May 24, 1988, which prohibits [[Local government in the United Kingdom|local authorities]] from "intentionally promoting homosexuality, publishing material with the intention of promoting homosexuality, or promoting the teaching in any [[State school|maintained school]] of the acceptability of homosexuality as a pretended family relationship."<ref>[http://www.opsi.gov.uk/acts/acts1988/Ukpga_19880009_en_5.htm Local Government Act 1988 (c. 9)], section 28. Accessed July 1, 2006 on opsi.gov.uk.</ref> The law was repealed in Scotland in 2000, as one of the first actions of the devolved [[Scottish Parliament]], and in the rest of the United Kingdom in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|title=Local Government Act 2003|url=http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2003/26/section/122|publisher=UK Government|accessdate=May 30, 2015}}</ref>
==State laws== ===Alabama=== "Course materials and instruction that relate to sexual education or sexually transmitted diseases should include . . . an emphasis, in a factual manner and from a public health perspective, that homosexuality is not a lifestyle acceptable to the general public and that homosexual conduct is a criminal offense under the laws of the state." Ala. Code § 16-40A-2.<ref name="lambda2">{{cite web|url=http://www.lambdalegal.org/dont-erase-us/laws|title=#DontEraseUs: State Anti-LGBT Curriculum Laws|publisher=|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://alisondb.legislature.state.al.us/alison/codeofalabama/1975/coatoc.htm|title=Code of Alabama 1975|website=Alabama Legislature|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref>
===Arizona=== "No district shall include in its course of study instruction which: 1. Promotes a homosexual life-style. 2. Portrays homosexuality as a positive alternative life-style. 3. Suggests that some methods of sex are safe methods of homosexual sex." ARS § 15-716.<ref name="lambda2"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azleg.gov/ars/15/00716.htm|title=15-716 - Instruction on acquired immune deficiency syndrome; department assistance|website=www.azleg.gov|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref>
===Louisiana=== "No sex education course offered in the public schools of the state shall utilize any sexually explicit materials depicting male or female homosexual activity . . . The major emphasis of any sex education instruction offered in the public schools of this state shall be to encourage sexual abstinence between unmarried persons and any such instruction shall: . . . Emphasize abstinence from sexual activity outside of marriage as the expected standard for all school-age children." La. R.S. § 17:281.<ref name="lambda2"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legis.la.gov/Legis/Law.aspx?d=80423|title=Louisiana State Legislature|website=www.legis.la.gov|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref>
===Mississippi=== "Abstinence-only education shall remain the state standard for any sex-related education taught in the public schools. For purposes of this section, abstinence-only education includes any type of instruction or program which, at an appropriate age . . . [t]eaches the current state law related to sexual conduct, including forcible rape, statutory rape, . . . and homosexual activity . . . and teaches that a mutually faithful, monogamous relationship in the context of marriage is the only appropriate setting for sexual intercourse." Miss. Code § 37-13-171.<ref name="lambda2"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://law.justia.com/codes/mississippi/2010/title-37/13/37-13-171|title=2010 Mississippi Code :: TITLE 37 - EDUCATION :: :: Chapter 13 - Curriculum; School Year and Attendance. :: 37-13-171 - Abstinence education; components; exception to requirement; parent programs.|publisher=|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref>
===Oklahoma=== "AIDS prevention education shall specifically teach students that: 1. engaging in homosexual activity, promiscuous sexual activity, intravenous drug use or contact with contaminated blood products is now known to be primarily responsible for contact with the AIDS virus; 2. avoiding the activities specified in paragraph 1 of this subsection is the only method of preventing the spread of the virus." 70 Okla. Stat. § 11-103.3.<ref name="lambda2"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oscn.net/applications/oscn/DeliverDocument.asp?CiteID=90134|title=AIDS Prevention Education|website=www.oscn.net|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref>
===South Carolina=== "The program of instruction provided for in this section may not include a discussion of alternative sexual lifestyles from heterosexual relationships including, but not limited to, homosexual relationships except in the context of instruction concerning sexually transmitted diseases." S.C. Code § 59-32-30(A).<ref name="lambda2"/><ref>{{cite web|website=South Carolina Legislature|url=https://www.scstatehouse.gov/code/t59c032.php|title=Code of Laws - Title 59 - Chapter 32 - Comprehensive Health Education Program|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref>
===Texas=== "The materials in the education programs intended for persons younger than 18 years of age must: (1) emphasize sexual abstinence before marriage and fidelity in marriage as the expected standard . . . and (2) state that homosexual conduct is not an acceptable lifestyle and is a criminal offense under Section 21.06, Penal Code." Tex. Health & Safety Code § 85.007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.statutes.legis.state.tx.us/Docs/HS/htm/HS.85.htm|title=Health and Safety Code Chapter 85. Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome and Human Immunodeficiency Virus Infection|website=Texas Legislature|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref>
"Course materials and instruction relating to sexual education or sexually transmitted diseases should include: emphasis, provided in a factual manner and from a public health perspective, that homosexuality is not a lifestyle acceptable to the general public and that homosexual conduct is a criminal offense under Section 21.06, Penal Code." Tex. Health & Safety Code § 163.002.<ref name="lambda2"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.statutes.legis.state.tx.us/Docs/HS/htm/HS.163.htm|title=Health and Safety Code Chapter 163. Education Program About Sexual Conduct and Substance Abuse|website=Texas Legislature|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref>
==Repealed Laws== ===North Carolina=== In 2006 with the passage of 2006 N.C. Sess. Laws 264,§ 54(a)–(c), the North Carolina State Legislature amended N.C. Gen. Stat. § 115C-81(e1)(3) to remove the prohibition of discussing homosexuality.<ref>{{cite journal |last= Cooley|first= Amanda|last2= Harmon|first2= |date= 2015|title= Constitutional Representations of the Family in Public Schools: Ensuring Equal Protection for All Students Regardless of Parental Sexual Orientation or Gender Identity|url= http://moritzlaw.osu.edu/students/groups/oslj/files/2016/01/Vol.-76_5-1007-1050-Cooley-Article1.pdf|journal= Ohio State Law Journal|volume= 76|issue= 5|pages= 1023|doi= |access-date= }}</ref>
===Utah=== On October 21, 2016, [[Equality Utah]] filed a lawsuit with the [[U.S. District Court for the District of Utah]] against the [[Utah Education Association|Utah State Board of Education]] to strike down Utah Code § 53A-13-101(1)(c)(iii)(A).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nclrights.org/cases-and-policy/cases-and-advocacy/case-equality-utah-v-utah-state-board-of-education/|title=Case: Equality Utah v. Utah State Board of Education|date=21 October 2016|publisher=National Center for Lesbian Rights|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref> On March 8, 2017, the [[Utah State Legislature]] passed SB196, which removes the phrase "the advocacy of homosexuality" from the law.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sltrib.com/news/5031887-155/utah-legislature-strikes-so-called-no-promo-homo|title=Utah Legislature strikes so-called 'no-promo homo' law|work=The Salt Lake Tribune|date=March 8, 2017|last=Harrie|first=Dan|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://le.utah.gov/~2017/bills/static/SB0196.html|title=SB0196|website=Utah State Legislature|accessdate=28 August 2018}}</ref> On March 20, 2017, Governor [[Gary Herbert]] signed SB196 into law. The law went into effect on July 1, 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://fox13now.com/2017/03/20/utah-governor-repeals-law-forbidding-promotion-of-homosexuality-in-schools/|title=Utah governor repeals law forbidding 'promotion' of homosexuality in schools|last=Winslow|first=Ben|date=20 March 2017|location=Salt Lake City|pages=|newspaper=FOX 13}}</ref>
The repealed [[statute]] stated "[T]he materials adopted by a local school board ... shall be based upon recommendations of the school district's Curriculum Materials Review Committee that comply with state law and state board rules emphasizing [[Abstinence-only sex education|abstinence]] before marriage and [[fidelity]] after marriage, and prohibiting instruction in the advocacy of homosexuality." Utah Code § 53A-13-101.<ref name="lambda2"/>
==See also== * [[LGBT rights in the United States]] * [[Russian gay propaganda law]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{LGBT rights in the United States}}
[[Category:LGBT law in the United States]] [[Category:United States education law]] [[Category:Textbook controversies]]

page.title: Pedagogy of Hope: Reliving Pedagogy of the Oppressed

revision.text:
'''''Pedagogy of Hope: Reliving Pedagogy of the Oppressed''''' ([[Portuguese language|Portuguese]]'': Pedagogia da Esperança: Um reencontro com a Pedagogia do Oprimido'') is a 1992 book written by [[Paulo Freire]] that contains his reflections and elaborations on his previous book ''[[Pedagogy of the Oppressed]]'', with a focus on hope. It was first published in Portuguese in 1992 and was translated into English in 1994 by Robert Barr, with notes from Freire's widow Ana Maria Araújo Freire.
== Summary == ''Pedagogy of Hope'' is broken up into seven chapters, along with an "Opening Words" section and an "Afterwards". In the book, Freire offers his reflections on the thinking behind ''Pedagogy of the Oppressed''. Unlike in his previous book, Freire centralizes the theme of hope and introduces it as an "[[Ontology|ontological]] need".<ref>{{Cite book|title=Pedagogy of Hope: Reliving Pedagogy of the Oppressed|last=Freire|first=Paolo|publisher=Bloomsbury|year=2014|isbn=978-1-4725-3340-1|location=Great Britain|pages=2}}</ref> He notes that although hope alone is not enough to achieve liberation, without hope there is no struggle at all. Freire emphasizes the importance of the relationship between educators and students and continues to fight against the [[banking model of education]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=Pedagogy of Hope: Reliving Pedagogy of the Oppressed|last=Freire|first=Paolo|publisher=Bloomsbury|year=2014|isbn=978-1-4725-3340-1|location=Great Britain|pages=102}}</ref>
In the "Afterwards", Ana Maria Araújo Freire reflects on her husband's work, and concludes by introducing the triangle of her reading of the world: "prohibition, liberation, and hope".<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Mary Ellen|first=Sullivan|date=Fall 1994|title=Pedagogy of Hope: Reliving Pedagogy of the Oppressed}}</ref>
== Critical reception == Scholar Timothy D. Ireland argues that Freire does not offer anything new in ''Pedagogy of Hope''; rather, he argues, the merit of the book is Freire's willingness to expound and clarify his work.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ireland|first=Timothy D.|date=1994|title=Pedagogy of Hope (Book Review).|url=|journal=Convergence|volume=27|issue=2-3|pages=198|via=}}</ref> Denis Collins offers a similar view, noting that he could not identify new concerns or theories put forward by Freire.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Collins|first=Denis E.|date=1998|title=Review Essay: From Oppression to Hope: Freire's Journey Toward Utopia|url=|journal=Anthropology & Education Quarterly|volume=29|pages=115–124}}</ref> Mary Ellen Sullivan asserts that Freire has an almost [[Stream of consciousness (narrative mode)|stream of consciousness]] style of writing, making the translation "awkward [and] literal".<ref name=":3" /> Conversely, Sarah Hendriks argues that "Freire's dialogical method of writing, as if he were letting us read the very pages of his personal diary, captivates his audience and thus his message becomes personally applicable to our own lives and practice of education".<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://fcis.oise.utoronto.ca/~daniel_sc/freire/sh.html|title=Pedagogy of Hope: Reliving Pedagogy of the Oppressed. (Review)|last=Hendriks|first=Sarah|date=|website=Reviews of Paolo Freire's Books|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-18}}</ref> Hendriks also critiques Freire's concept of "unity in diversity", noting that it is overly focused on class struggle and does not acknowledge how people can be victims of multiple forms of oppression at the same time.<ref name=":0" />
Sullivan also asserts that Freire is: "Uncompromisingly on the side of oppressed peoples everywhere, Freire promotes his philosophically dense ideas with the fervor of a revolutionary.”<ref name=":3" /> Additionally, Collins makes a point to acknowledge that Freire "makes profound apologies for apparent sexism in his earlier writings".<ref name=":2" /> Shelli B. Fowler contends that Freire promoted teaching as acts of creativity--acts that should always be critical and never be mechanical. She also asserts that one of Freire's most fundamental points was that teachers need to teach students how to teach themselves.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fowler|first=Shelli B.|date=1998|title=“Under the Shade of this Mango Tree”: Reflections on a Pedagogical Practice that Crosses Disciplinary Boundaries|url=|journal=Quest|volume=50|issue=3|pages=319-323|via=}}</ref>
== References == <references />
[[Category:1992 books]] [[Category:Pedagogy]] [[Category:Popular education]] [[Category:Education books]] [[Category:Critical pedagogy]]

{{Unreferenced|date=October 2016}}
In [[Malaysia]], '''Pendidikan Moral''' ([[Malay language|Malay]] for "Moral Studies") is one of the core subjects in the [[Sijil Pelajaran Malaysia]] (SPM) examination. It is a required subject for all non-Muslim students in the [[Education in Malaysia|public education system in Malaysia]]. Muslim students are required to take the Islamic Studies ({{lang-ms|Pendidikan Islam}}) course. Pendidikan Moral, along with Islamic Studies, is governed by the Department of Islamic and Moral Studies (JAPIM), a branch under the [[Ministry of Higher Education (Malaysia)|Ministry of Higher Education]].
==Syllabus== The core of the syllabus is the 36 [[moral value]]s (called "nilai" in Malay). These values include "''Kepercayaan kepada Tuhan''" (creed), "''Bertanggungjawab''" (responsibility) and "''Sikap Keterbukaan''" (open-mindedness) among others. The 36 values are divided categorized into 7 major fields of study (called "bidang" in Malay), namely:
* ''Perkembangan Diri'' ([[self-help|self-development]]) * ''Kekeluargaan'' ([[family]]) * ''Alam Sekitar'' ([[nature]]) * ''Patriotisme'' ([[patriotism]]) * ''Hak Asasi Manusia'' ([[human rights]]) * ''Demokrasi'' ([[democracy]]) * ''Keamanan dan Keharmonian'' ([[peace]] and harmony).
These values are presented in detail in textbooks and form the basis of corresponding examinations. Each value is defined by the Education Ministry. Answering examination questions requires some interpretation of these definitions.
Students are required to provide the exact same definitions of each moral value when answering exam questions. If a student misspelled or left out or word or rephrased the definition without changing its meaning, no marks will be given. Not fully memorizing the definitions is the reason why students always fail to secure an A+.
==Examination== Pendidikan Moral is often learned by [[Rote learning|rote]]. Teachers in schools tend to concentrate on answering techniques rather than the teaching material provided in the textbook. Instead of interpreting the appropriate value based on the information given, students are taught to look for specific keywords in the description and identify the corresponding moral value. Thus, strict memorization of the values is required without any emphasis on understanding or application. There have been suggestions to reform the system and incorporate other forms of assessment and not rely completely on written examinations but thus far, they have not been implemented.<!--<ref>[http://myais.fsktm.um.edu.my/5116/1/10.pdf]. Assessment in Moral Education at the Secondary School Level: Theoretical and Practical Perspectives</ref>-->
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.moe.gov.my/tayang.php?laman=home&bhs=my Ministry of Education Malaysia] *[http://www.japim.edu.my/ Department of Islamic and Moral Studies] *[https://www.aanwijzing.com/2017/12/definisi-lingkungan-pendidikan.html Lingkungan Pendidikan]

{{Infobox organization | name = Sino-American Youth Ambassadors | native_name = 中美青年大使 | logo = Sino-American_Youth_Ambassadors_program_official_logo.png | headquarters = [[Washington, D.C.]] | parent_organization = [[Ameson Education and Cultural Exchange Foundation]] | location = [[People's Republic of China]] and United States | founded_date = 2010 | website = {{Official website|http://www.ameson.org/programs/capacity-building/saya/}} | abbreviation = SAYA }}
'''Sino-American Youth Ambassador (SAYA)''' ([[Simplified Chinese characters|Chinese Simplified]]: 中美青年大使; [[Pinyin]]: zhōngměi qīngnián dàshǐ) is an [[Student exchange program|exchange program]] run by the [[Ameson Education and Cultural Exchange Foundation]] seeking to build capacity for campus internationalization and cultural awareness in school campuses. Currently, SAYA program is open to Chinese and American students who serve as cultural ambassadors in both countries.
==Background==
The Sino-American Youth Ambassadors (SAYA) program started in 2010 as part of the [[Ameson Education and Cultural Exchange Foundation|Ameson Foundation]]'s program with the intention of bringing greater international awareness and cultural diversity in campus with American and Chinese high school students.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ameson.org/programs/capacity-building/saya |title=SAYA Program page |website=ameson.org|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref> The SAYA program seeks to build capacity for international education and provide new perspectives on education by exchanging student ambassadors. Each year, SAYA organizes two exchanges: one is American students go abroad in China and the other is Chinese students go abroad in United States. In 2012, approximately 20 American students participated the SAYA program in Beijing No. 4 High School where they learned Chinese language and cultural with SAYA Chinese students and travelled with their Chinese peers. In the return exchange in 2012, SAYA students had an opportunity to meet the U.S. Vice President, [[Joe Biden]] and the Chinese current [[paramount leader]], [[Xi Jinping]] during the exchange program in Los Angeles.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ameson.org/foundation-news/1376-joe-biden-and-xi-jinping-meet-with-ameson-saya-students-joe-biden-and-xi-jinping-meet-with-ameson-saya-students |title= Joe Biden and Xi Jinping meet with Ameson SAYA Students|website=amesn.org|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref> In 2013, approximately 100 Chinese students participated the SAYA program during the Chinese New Year and introduced the Chinese New Year traditions to their American classmates in [[Belmont High School (Belmont, Wisconsin)|Belmont High School]], Thomas Jefferson High School, and [[Providence Day School]] and host families in the community.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ameson.org/events/1453-saya-2013-saya-2013|title= Largest SAYA exchange to date concludes successfully|website=ameson.org|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref> In return exchanges, students from Branson High School visited [[Shanghai]] Gezhi High School,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ameson.org/events/1454-changing-places-gezhi|title= Changing places: Branson students visit Shanghai Gezhi High School|website=ameson.org|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref> and students from [[Providence Day School]] visited Jingling High School’s Hexi campus<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ameson.org/events/1500-saya-2013-hexi |title= Latest SAYA exchange comes to Hexi|website=ameson.org|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref> later in the year 2013.
==Program==
SAYA programs take place during school holidays. Prior to the exchange, students undergo cultural training to learn about different cultures. During the exchange students immerse themselves in regular classes for a week and travel with their peers for another week.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://usa.chinadaily.com.cn/us/2016-02/10/content_23442519.htm|last= Hua ShengDun|title=Students bring Chinese culture to US high schools|website=usa.chinadaily.com.cn|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref> As cultural ambassadors, students share their culture with other students through [[presentation]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/local/madeira/2016/01/28/madeiraschools/79454692/|last= Sheila A. Vilven|title=Madeira City Schools host Chinese student ambassadors|website=www.cincinnati.com|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref> After the exchange, students return to their countries and share what they learned with classmates.
SAYA connects American and Chinese high schools interested in cultural exchanges and arranges home-stays for participants.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.burnettcountysentinel.com/news/chinese-students-enjoy-grantsburg-visit/article_2ddb477e-d001-11e5-a52c-b3259c3fa815.html|last=Steve Briggs Sentinel|title=Chinese students enjoy Grantsburg visit|website=www.burnettcountysentinel.com|access-date=2016-03-04}}</ref> SAYA serves as an intermediary between American and Chinese students to facilitate cultural exchanges in personal level.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.ameson.org/programs/capacity-building/saya SAYA Main Page] * [http://www.ameson.org/news News articles for Ameson Foundation] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160213091742/http://world.people.com.cn/n1/2016/0212/c1002-28120376.html] “我们没有什么不同”, 人民网, world.people.com.cn, in Chinese * [http://www.worldjournal.com/3730549/article-120%E5%90%8D%E4%B8%AD%E5%9C%8B%E9%AB%98%E4%B8%AD%E7%94%9F-%E4%BE%86%E7%BE%8E%E4%BA%A4%E6%B5%81/ "120名「中美青年大使」 來美交流", 世界新聞網, www.worldjournal.com] in Chinese
[[Category:Cultural exchange]] [[Category:Student exchange]]

'''Southwest Forestry University''' ({{zh|c=西南林业大学|p=Xīnán Línyèdàxué}}; '''SWFU''') is the largest forestry university in the southwestern part of China. It is a comprehensive university, consisting of 18 professional departments. It is in Kunming city, founded in 1939.
==Facilities== As of February 2016, the school covered 1800 acres, which includes 1204.1 acres of campus, teaching experimental forest of 693 acres, building area of 450,000 square meters; teaching equipment research equipment worth 123 million yuan; 72 undergraduate majors; 16,451 full-time undergraduate students; 1230 full-time graduate students.
SWFU has 1,170 staff members that include 775 instructors — 86% of whom hold a master’s degree and above. These include 350 professors and associate professors, 18 mentors for PhD candidates. Some of the professors and scholars are well-known domestically and internationally.
The university raised 253 million Chinese yuan of research funds in the past five years;{{when?|date=May 2018}} won one second prize of the State Award for Science and Technology Advancement and 24 other awards for completed projects; and two first prizes of the Natural Sciences Award of Yunnan Province. More than 3,000 papers, 110 monographs and six translated monographs have been published.
==International ties== The university has established cooperative and exchange ties with universities and research institutes in the United States, Canada, France, Germany, Netherlands, Australia, New Zealand, Japan, Thailand, Philippines and Vietnam for joint research and training of graduate and undergraduate students.
Based on reciprocally transferable credit programs, SWFU has developed joint-education programs for undergraduate students based on the “2+2” models, as well as dispatching exchange graduate students for field practicum mandatory for thesis research with universities in the United States, Canada, Netherlands, Thailand, Poland, and Vietnam.
Joint research and training programs have been conducted in cooperation with the World Wildlife Fund (WWF), Rare Conservation, Global Environment Facility (GEF), The Nature Conservancy (TNC), MacArthur Foundation, and Ford Foundation.
== References == * https://web.archive.org/web/20160105233410/http://en.swfu.edu.cn/ * http://en.swfu.edu.cn/about.html
== External links == * http://www.swfu.edu.cn/

{{Infobox television | show_name = The Carol Duvall Show | image = | caption = | show_name_2 = | genre = Family entertainment | creator = | developer = | writer = | director = Don Colliver
Jim Stimpson | creative_director = | presenter = [[Carol Duvall]] | starring = | judges = | voices = | narrated = | theme_music_composer = | opentheme = | endtheme = | composer = | country = {{USA}} | language = [[English language|English]] | num_seasons = | num_episodes = | list_episodes = | executive_producer = | producer = | editor = | location = | cinematography = | camera = | runtime = | company = Weller/Grossman Productions | distributor = | channel = [[HGTV]] | picture_format = | audio_format = | first_run = | first_aired = 1 December 1994 | last_aired = 2005 | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = | website = | production_website = }} '''''The Carol Duvall Show''''' is an arts and crafts show which aired on the [[HGTV]] cable channel from 1994 to 2005 hosted by [[Carol Duvall]]. It was also broadcast on the [[DIY Network]] from 2005 until late-2009. Recordings of segments from the show can be viewed on their website. The show is devoted to demonstrating and teaching a wide variety of crafts from very basic "cut and glue" projects to intricate polymer clay creations. Duvall's program was one of the original offerings on the newly founded Home & Garden Television network in 1994, and it has remained one of the lifestyle network's most popular shows throughout its 12-year run. She introduced many polymer clay artists to the community including Judy Belcher, Maureen Carlson, Kim Cavender, Katherine Dewey, Emi Fukushima, Syndee Holt, Debbie Jackson, [[Donna Kato]], [[Barbara McGuire]], Ann Mitchell, Karen Mitchell, Becky Meverden, Lisa Pavelka, Gail Ritchey, Nan Roche, Michelle Ross, and Bob Wiley who have inspired countless polymer enthusiasts. The show also featured interviews with crafters and fine artists - painters, sculptors, glass-blowers, etc. with footage of them at work in their studios. The cancellation of the show on HGTV caused dismay among many of her fans;[http://newsgroups.derkeiler.com/Archive/Rec/rec.crafts.beads/2006-02/msg00130.html newsgroups.derkeiler.com] whose protests might have influenced the decision to continue broadcasting it on the [[DIY Network]] (owned by the same parent company [[Scripps Networks]]).{{Cite web|url=http://www.diynetwork.com/carol-duvall-bio/bio/index.html|title=Carol Duvall Bio : DIY Network|last=|first=|date=2012-10-08|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121008185139/http://www.diynetwork.com/carol-duvall-bio/bio/index.html|archive-date=2012-10-08|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-03}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==Sources== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070517124233/http://www.hgtv.com/hgtv/shows_cds ''The Carol Duvall Show''] *[http://www.terrawellington.com/Column2004/102704.htm Carol Duvall Balances Her Life]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Carol Duvall Show, The}} [[Category:HGTV original programs]] [[Category:1994 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2005 American television series endings]] [[Category:Arts and crafts television series]] {{nonfiction-tv-prog-stub}}
